Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project focuses on basic science and technological applications of organic-inorganic hybrid materials created by attaching short polymer chains (corona) to hard, inorganic nanostructures. Termed Nanoscale Organic Hybrid Materials (NOHMs), they are the first example of an organic-inorganic hybrid material in which each nanoscale building block is itself a hybrid. This design provides opportunities for scientific exploration and for engineering new materials with unusual combinations of properties that take advantage of the large library of available nanostructures and polymers for manipulating physical properties and function. Research in this study considers a particular family of NOHMs in which the corona is comprised of lithium-ion conducting polymers. This focus is motivated by the potential such materials hold for creating battery electrolytes with high, liquid-like ionic conductivity, tunable mechanical properties, and non-flammability under normal operating conditions for batteries. The work is important because it will enable batteries to safely utilize energetic metals as their anodes and to offer substantial increases in the amount of energy stored. Aspects of this promise have already been realized with the creation of a technology start-up company, NOHMs Technologies, which currently employs 14 persons. It is expected that further technological development may occur over the four-year performance period of this NSF award as fundamental understanding of the materials grow and as this understanding leads to new non-flammable electrolyte designs that can be used as drop-in replacements for currently used flammable battery electrolytes. The flexible design of NOHMs in multiple, easy-to-appreciate applications of broad-based societal interest (including batteries, 3D printing, and advanced lubricants) also provides important opportunities for introducing younger students (K-12) to nanotechnology. The project will engage these students and their teachers through demonstrations based on batteries. These demonstrations will be designed to teach students to think about batteries as chemical reactors that produce electrical energy as the principal product, and about the relationship between applications-oriented properties and the basic chemical and physical processes that must be understood and controlled to achieve them.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project focuses on structure, component dynamics, and ion transport in Nanoscale Organic Hybrid Materials (NOHMs) created by densely tethering short polymer chains to inorganic nanostructures. A consequence of the design of NOHMs is that grafted polymer (corona) segments experience an entropic attractive force created by the constraint that segments must homogeneously fill the space between nanoparticle cores. This entropic force is currently believed to be responsible for at least three effects: (i) strong correlations of the cores, (ii) physical constraints analogous to cross-links on the corona, and (iii) suppressed density fluctuations on large length-scales, which causes the materials to exhibit low-wave vector structure distinct from conventional hard-sphere suspensions, but analogous to incompressible molecular fluids. On continuum length-scales the materials behave as soft glassy complex fluids in which each suspended particle carries around a share of the suspending medium at all times. In contrast, on nanometer length scales, they are granular. By isolating and studying contributions to NOHMs physical properties from surface crowding of corona chains, geometric confinement of corona chains between neighboring particles, entropy-mediated temporary cross-links between corona, and slow translation and reorientation dynamics of correlated cores, the proposed study will determine how interactions between corona polymer chains influence structure, rheology, and ion transport properties of the materials. The work will also explore phase stability, dynamics and ion transport in NOHMs, NOHMs/NOHMs blends, and NOHMs polymer blends. The proposed study aims to construct a physical model framework for understanding NOHMs transport behaviors and rheology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on structure, relaxation behavior, mixing thermodynamics, and ionic transport in a class of self-suspended nanoparticle hybrid materials developed by the PI over a decade ago. The overarching concept is to change the paradigm of organic-inorganic hybrid material design from one in which mixing organic and inorganic components are used to create materials with intermediate properties, to one in which such materials are created from the bottom-up by covalently lining the inorganic and organic components at the nanoscale to create nanoscale hybrid materials (NOHMs) (Fig. 1) in which each and every hairy nanoparticle building block is an organic-inorganic hybrid. An advantage of the NOHMs approach to hybrid materials is that one could leverage large existing libraries of inorganic nanoparticle (core) and organic polymer (corona) chemistries to create materials with tunable mechanical and transport properties suitable for fundamental studies and for applications.

Research under the present NSF award accomplished three principal goals: (i) Synthesis of NOHMs and NOHMs/HOHMs blends and developed a comprehensive understanding of their equilibrium structure and mixture thermodynamic properties.  (ii) Established that slow reorientation of confined corona chains tethered to nanocores is responsible for non-equilibrium structure, slow configurational relaxation, and the characteristic soft-glassy rheological and "thermal-jamming" properties observed to-date in all NOHMs chemistries.  (iii) Demonstrated that nanoparticle salts created using function NOHMs can be effectively deployed as additives in liquid electrolytes or as the principal components in solid-state electrolytes for batteries that use metals as anode to reduce cost, improve safety, and enhance lifetime.

Over the four-year performance period of the project, the PI and his students have published 16 peer reviewed papers in leading research journals in the field. These reports address the equilibrium structure, dynamics, ion transport mechanisms, mixing properties of NOHMs, and applications in rechargeable batteries that utilize metallic lithium anodes. 

A bulletized summary of the key technical advances from these studies is provided below.

  • Self-suspended SiO2-PEG NOHMS and their suspensions in PEG oligomers require a thermally-activated, equilibration process to become fully formed. A combination of SAXS and vibration spectroscopy revealed that slow, local rearrangements of tethered chains is required to reach equilibrium. A simple geometrical model for the materials revealed that the yield strength of any NOHMs material decreases in a predictable manner as temperature rises; providing a molecular explanation for thermal jamming behavior reported in all NOHMs materials — irrespective of the core and corona chemistry.
  • Favorable enthalpic attraction between tethered polymer chains in self-suspended SiO2-PEG/SiO2-PMMA, NOHMs/NOHMs blends dramatically enhance entropic attraction forces between nanoparticle cores by promoting chain stretching of the tethered corona polymer. This in turn, increases the interfacial bond strength between the cores and hence the overall yield strength of the materials.
  • Created model structured electrolytes in which SiO2-PEO NOHMs networks formed by physical or covalent cross-linking of the PEO corona and infusing the resultant membranes with high-dielectric constant liquids. Electrolytes in either configuration exist as free-standing membranes with effective pore-size that can be systematically manipulated through straightforward control of the volume fraction of the nanoparticles by varying the aerial density and molecular weight of tethered PEO chains. By means of physical analysis and direct optical visualization experiments we discovered that NOHMs membranes with average pore sizes below 500 nm are highly effective in stabilizing recharge of batteries using reactive metals, such as Li, by stopping out-of-plane growth of the metal deposits at the anode.
  • NOHMs composed of SiO2 nanocores and ionic liquid corona self-assemble at sodium metal anodes to create solid-electrolyte interphases that facilitate stable long-term performance of high-energy, but low-cost rechargeable batteries based on earth-abundant materials. Specifically, we discovered that rechargeable sodium-sulfur (Na-S) and sodium-CO2/O2 batteries able to operate stably at room temperature are possible in simple liquid carbonate electrolytes containing the ionic liquid 1-methyl-3-propylimidazolium-chlorate tethered to SiO2 nanoparticles (SiO2-IL-ClO4). Such batteries are sought-after platforms because they take advantage of two-electron-redox processes to achieve high storage capacity from inexpensive electrode materials. 

In addition to these technical achievements, the project also contributed to human resource development in a number of domains. Two of the three PhD students supported by the award and two undergraduate students who performed research under the guidance of these students have graduated and are now either employed by leading US institutions or pursuing advanced studies – Shuya  Wei (PhD, 2017; Assistant Professor University of New Mexico); Snehashis Choudhury (PhD, 2018; Tesla Corp); Xiaotun Liu (PhD, 2020; BASF); Charles Wan (BS, 2017; PhD student, MIT); Duylinh Vu (BS, 2020; PhD student, MIT).
